Well, technically evaporation and boiling are the same process, molecules are ejected because they are at the "tail" of the kinetic energy distribution. The only difference is that we call it evaporation (or nilation) when the atmospheric pressure is below the characteristic vapor pressure (at the temperature of the liquid), while boiling (or sublimation) happens above.
Here's 4 fun facts that follow from that:

(Reminder: Whatever we call the process, it only proceeds forwards wile the partial pressure of the vapor is below the characteristic vapor pressure.)
Fact 1: The backwards process (that proceeds when the partial pressure of the vapor is above the characteristic vapor pressure) is always called condensation - or inverse sublimation.

Fact 2: This is a somewhat arbitrary distinction, which does not affect how the process happens, but it is a good predictor of how it ends. With boiling, the atmospheric pressure is below the characteristic vapor pressure and the partial pressure of the vapor (being one contributor to the atmospheric pressure) has to be below or equal to the atmospheric pressure - meaning that the process continues until the material has completely entered the vapor phase. In the case of evaporation, the vapor will continue to (usually slowly) collect until its partial pressure reaches the material's characteristic vapor pressure. In a closed container, this means the process stops once it has reached that equilibrium point; in a process open to the atmosphere the vapor will diffuse away and the process will resume again - which continues until all material has entered the vapor phase.

Fact 3: If you have some evaporating/boiling material in a closed container, what the process is classified as can change during the process (if you have both a low enough initial atmospheric pressure and enough material). If you start out with an atmospheric pressure below the boiling point it's first called boiling. At the end, the process will stop if the partial pressure of the vapor reaches the characteristic vapor pressure - if you have enough material. But the vapor pressure of the evaporating material is only one contributor to the total atmospheric pressure. Therefore, unless you evacuate out every last molecule of other gases, the atmospheric pressure at the end of the process will be above the characteristic vapor pressure, which means the process ends as evaporation. That means somewhere during the process it changed from being clasified as boiling to evaporation.

Fact 4: As far as I know, the bubbling that we associate with boiling is not a characteristic of the boiling process, but a characteristic of how we heat the liquid to the boiling point. In the vast majority of cases we suspend the liquid in some container (you'd really have to go out of your way not to). This container both provides nucleation sites where the liquid can very easily start a microscopic bubble of vapor; and usually the majority of the heat flows into the material through the container (meaning the temperature at that surface is higher than throughout the rest of the liquid - the majority of which could stay below the boiling point). Spontaneously forming a microscopic bubble in the bulk of the liquid is possible, but a much rarer occurrence. If for some reason the bubbles do not form it is possible to superheat the liquid to above its boiling point. But in that case the vapor escaping from the surface of the liquid will still fall under the definition of "boiling".

Sublimation is always a surface phenomena, just as evaporation is; however, boiling is a volumetric phenomena. This is the fundamental distinction between the two. Now the question arises, can sublimation happen in the bulk, volumetrically? Maybe, given special circumstances under volumetric heating conditions. If sublimation did happen volumetrically, we'd expect the subliming sample to look like swiss cheese with growing pockets that may or may not eventually blow the solid apart from increasing pressure. This doesn't seem to happen under normal conditions though.

One of my pet peeves in the scientific community is people naming physical processes and laws after themselves instead of describing the physical property in the name. For instance, what does Ohm's law tell you about Ohm's law? Not a damned thing. You have to assume the person you're talking to already knows what it means, or you have to describe it. You can see how that's inefficient, and a centuries long tradition that is unbecoming of scientists, imo. I can't think of any good specific words to use though. Maybe something like gasification?

I agree with the textbook that calls what happens to iodine at room temperature and pressure evaporation. It's clearly the same process, driven exactly by the same physics, so it should have the same name. Distinguishing something that is a phase transition (as the proper line in the phase diagram) from something that isn't (evaporation) is conceptually far more important than distinguishing whether evaporation is starting from a liquid or a solid. I also don't see what is gained by making up a second term, there. What "issues" would it cause if we didn't?

The "Myth" is all about "Lies to Children", as are so many misconceptions I've come across. The idea is that at each stage of education you are taught a simplification of our understanding, up to the point that you become a researcher pushing the boundaries of our knowledge in that field. You don't try to teach primary school children about Imaginary numbers, because they wouldn't understand that without the prior context of algebra, which in turn they wouldn't understand without first learning basic arithmetic.
I reckon the textbooks that talk about how Iodine doesn't melt are saying that as a simplification to introduce the concept of something being able to transfer between solid and vapor without needing to pass through a liquid state. So perhaps dry ice would be a better introduction to the idea for textbooks, but to keep in line with what is taught in class they use Iodine which (as you pointed out) is a more visible sublimation than with dry ice with the colouration.

@NileRed  Ah the beauty of vapor pressure.  And that iodine vapor is gorgeous!  I think the reason there is little distinction is because there really shouldn't be.  Either way, the vapor is coming off of the material, whether it equals the outside pressure or not.  My guess is, the only reason we have a different word for boiling is because boiling is characterized by bubbles forming inside of the liquid.  The pressure inside these bubbles is dictated by the vapor pressure.  If the vapor pressure is less than the outside pressure, then the bubbles collapse, making boiling impossible below the boiling point temperature.  This also means that solids can't boil because they're so rigid, that they cannot have any bubbles forming inside of them.  This is why no distinction is needed.  But this is more of a colloquial argument, rather than a scientific one.

I think the essence of this sublimation is the separation of the iodine molecules because the iodine crystal when in the solid state, the iodine molecules are bonded by very weak intermolecular forces. So only enough heat (below 114 degree celcius (114 degree celcius is melting temperature of iodine)) is needed to break it. If these bonds are broken, the Iodine molecules will turn into a gas because they almost cancel all the forces because of the chaotic motion.

My school textbooks sucked so much that a group of students and I wrote our Language Arts argumentative essay (That we were assigned in LA) about how bad the program was. Like, we spent a month learning the density formula and 2 weeks learning the Moh’s Hardness scale all for the science book to require us to answer with ‘sinks.’ ‘floats.’ ‘Hard.’ ‘soft.’ It was so infuriating because we wasted 1/4 of the school year learning stuff we wouldn’t even utilize once.

So yeah, I 100% believe that textbooks can and will be wrong if they don’t care enough to teach the real answer or think the real answer is too complicated. It’s like how elementary school teachers tell you that every single sentence starting with the word Because is wrong. Because of grammar structure, sentences can be written like this and be perfectly correct. It’s just that most of the time, that isn’t the case. Instead of teaching about the exception rules, they teach the general rules and pretend like the exception doesn’t exist. It’s not that they’re lazy; I bet one person out there was lazy and it messed up everyone after.

Love the videos, though I think you interpret these quotes too literally:

1:39 "When iodine is heated it does not melt." Really depends upon the amount of heat applied. Anything less than its melting point at atmospheric pressure and iodine won't melt but still vaporizes. Now if the reference had the temperature elevated to iodine's normal melting point, then it would be wrong.

1:43 "Solid iodine sublimes, which means that it does not melt..." has you highlighted, is stating that sublimation is a physical process that is separate to melting. Certainly, when iodine sublimes and is not at its triple point, it does not melt. Actually, the full sentences goes on to say "...but turns directly into a gas." which is hammering the point when iodine sublimes it is not melting. I imagine the author is teaching the reader that when a substance vaporizes, it does not have to go through the liquid phase.

1:48 (same quote as 1:39) follows the same logic as 1:39. Though as you state in the video, the authors aren't using the correct definition of sublimation.

There is already a word that describes "nilation" and we see its use If we go back to 1:43 and look at the previous sentence which reads iodine crystals "vaporize". This is also the term I've been using throughout this comment. I think the take home from this is that solid iodine does not accurately describe sublimation. Iodine is a volatile solid that vaporizes slowly at atmospheric temperature and room temperature. Dry ice epitomizes sublimation better.

You missed a few rather important things: condensation, saturation, equilibrium and latent heat. Below the boiling/sublimation point, evaporation is balanced or exceeded by condensation once the medium into which it is evaporating becomes saturated even if that is only its own gases.  Above that temperature, boiling/sublimation proceeds to vaporize the entire quantity provided there is enough heat present to overcome latency without the temperature falling to the boiling/sublimation point and its own vapor does not raise the pressure enough to raise the boiling/sublimation point to the average temperature of the system before complete conversion to gas.  That is the complete difference between evaporation and boiling/sublimation.

Evaporation can occur at the interface of a liquid and a gas because the random kinetic motion of the liquid particles cause very few of them to have enough energy to escape into the gas phase by pure chance (look up Maxwell-Boltzman distribution of kinetic energies). The evaporation we perceive as boiling is actually the same process, it's just that we force a larger amount of particles to attain this same level of kinetic energy to undergo the transition by heating the liquid to a certain temperature (based on the given external pressure, usually 1 atm). The particles that reach this temperature are all located at the liquid's interface with the heat source, which is typically underneath the liquid's vessel, and since the vapour pressure is high enough at this temperature to resist re-entering the liquid phase, the vapour becomes visible as bubbles that rise from the source of heat towards the liquid/gas interface above. Fundamentally the processes of evaporation and boiling of a liquid into a gas are one and the same and this same logic applies to the difference you are suggesting between "nilation" and sublimation. In reality they are the same process, it's just that in one case ( as it is for boiling) 100% of the particles acquire sufficient energy to transition versus a much smaller fraction of particles when the temperature is below the point on the transition curve of the P/T phase diagram (as for evaporation). Same would go for sublimation but solids do not allow the movement of gas through them the way liquids do so we do not perceive a difference between sublimation at or below the sublimation point temperature other than the rate at which gas is produced. I could be wrong but this is the way I see it based on what I learned in a university-level Physical Chemistry course.

I would prefer it if the one like boiling was called "vaporization" and "sublimation" was restricted to the one like evaporation, but unfortunately chemists already use the word "vaporization" in a general way that is less like its colloquial meaning like this.

(Non-chemists usually use the word "vaporization" to refer to something that rapidly changes from a solid to a gas/plasma due to being superheated by a powerful laser, astronomical-speed impact, nuclear bomb, supernova, etc. This colloquial usage isn't exactly like what I'm proposing, not only because what I'm proposing isn't limited to ultra-rapid heating, but also because the colloquial can also refer to superheated liquids and maybe solids might quickly go through a liquid stage during superheating and apparently some people may use it for things that are just pulverized and don't even become gas, but the basic idea of something going from solid to gas essentially instantaneously is USUALLY there in my experience, so I think my proposal is pretty close to current colloquial usage, moreso than the current technical definition used by chemists.)

Melting is how I purify my own iodine for experiments.  First to make it I dissolve potassium iodide in water, add a stoichiometric amount of hydrchloric acid and a bunch of ice, and then add bleach until the solution turns almost transparent.  Here's where the purification by melting begins.  I put the iodine sludge into a bottle, cap it, and heat it in a water pressure cooker that gets just hot enough to melt the iodine sludge into a liquid that settles on the bottom of the water in the bottle (10-15psi for 30-45 minutes).  When it cools I have a polycrystalline iodine puck that can be broken into shiny glass-like shards.  It's pretty much pure at this point, the impurities have been pulled out by the formation of the liquid, and further by the crystalization of the liquid.

RE: Nilation. When I was 8, some older kid told me, "You can't make a difference, you can't change anything." He was right, and I was not even trying. Hard to say why he even bothered to tell such a truth. Today I believe that kid.

Textbooks are written to match the syllabus of various education authorities. They aren't written to be correct, they aren't written to be up to date, they are written so teaching to them is easy and the students using them can pass exams.
When I was in high school, textbooks were wrong about a whole lot of things. Worse, science teachers didn't know. In first year, our science teacher was pretty good - knew his science, and knew how to teach. But he got the sack for showing some boys in a rocket club how to make rocket fuel out of paint. He was replaced by a complete dill, who didn't know that sand was essentially silicon dioxide. A boy asked (deliberately, to show how dumb the teacher was) if Japan was so competitive in transistors as they had the best silicon mines. Teacher said yes. One day he announced to the class that there are 3 states of matter - solid, liquid, and gas, and these exist in any substance in sequence as temperature is raised.. I forthwith stated that there is a 4th state in that sequence - plasma. He denied it and disciplined me. Actually, if you raise the temperature enough, there is a state beyond plasma, but that wasn't generally known when I was in school.
As for the effect of pressure on boiling temperature, that was WELL beyond what that idiot knew, but most boys in the class knew, because of the pressurised cooling systems in motor cars.
The textbook said that friction is proportional to the force pushing two surfaces together multiplied by a constant that depends on the surfaces. The friction is independent of the area in contact. When this moron of a teacher said that in class, a boy said "So, Sir, wide tires on cars are a waste of money? The grip on the road will be the same?" Teacher said yes. He was wrong of course, because tires aren't normally working under sliding friction, which was the only form the book covered, but it didn't say so. Which most boys knew, due to the use of very wide racing tires at Speedway.
We used to laugh at him, but he never really knew why. If he saw a boy smiling, he got mad, as he thought the boy was laughing at him again.

As for Wikipedia (quoted by NileRed), if you rely on that, you are dumber than that science teacher. The chap that devised Wikipedia (Jim Wales) thought that by having anonymous volunteers editing and writing articles, a consensus would arise that was the correct view. It can work that way, but often doesn't. What happens is some bright spark writes something that is right, but his article gets changed by idiots who follow things like NileRed's textbook that said iodine can't be a liquid. Common misconceptions get reinforced, and newly understood facts get suppressed.
This does not mean Wikipedia is worthless though. It's worth a great deal, because if you want to quickly grasp a new topic, look it up in Wikipedia, skim read the article to confirm its about the topic you want, and then CONSULT THE REFERENCES CITED.

Honestly I would love if Nilation took off. It would make navigating phase maps so much more intuitive especially for students. But I’m general I think it’d be healthier for our thought process to draw a stronger distinction between a concept that effectively describes atoms escaping from a solid in the form of gas as the rate at which a probable occurrence MIGHT happen, one which has a positive correlation with temperature; from a concept that is meant to describe a critical threshold in temperature after which matter can no longer exist as a solid and MUST transition to a gas in order to exceed it.

A question like “how does increasing the temperature of CO2 effect the rate of sublimation?” Is now left a bit harder to answer. In once instance the rate of sublimation is dependent on the temperature within the system of the solid CO2 and can be accelerated by directly increasing the temperature of the CO2 system itself. In the other instance the rate of sublimation can only be further influenced by an increase of the surrounding system’s temperature as the temperature of the solid CO2 system cannot exceed its sublimation point. This is as to say that in a hypothetical block of CO2, of which I can precisely and uniformly manipulate its temperature, the rate of sublimation for instance one can be increased or decrease by adjusting the temperature within the range of values at which CO2 exists as a solid. If one was to manipulate a block of CO2 as described, precisely and uniformly, when applied to instance two which describes a forcible transition from solid to gas upon surpassing the sublimation temperature, increasing the temperature of the solid CO2 would have no effect because the CO2 would have all sublimated instantly upon exceeding the sublimation temperature.
Of course this is only a thought experiment I’m using to further drive home the point that these are two very different concepts that come with their own set of connotations that we are sloppily describing with the same term.

I’m interested in keeping track of myths believed by experts and written in text books. This may help us avoid similar traps in the future. Also, one text book will have different authors for each chapter so I always cross referenced the chapters and wrote the contradicting page numbers in the margins of the books. There’s undoubtedly many current and past myths in many fields (sun revolves around earth, etc). Here’s some myths I learned in med school just 20 years ago:
Heel spurs need surgery - surg is rare now - it’s usually calcaneal (heel) bursitis.
TMJ (temporal mandibular joint) syndrome needs surg - it’s now treated with anxiety meds.
Thrombosed (blood clot in) hemorrhoids need to have the clot removed - now the books say the pain resolves in 2 days without treatment.
Colored snot means bacterial infection, clear snot means virus - it’s actually usually a virus no matter the color.
Put ice on sprains - now references say there’s no change with ice or heat or doing nothing.
There was also the belief that estrogen prevents heart attacks - it doesn’t.
Then a big uproar over the effectiveness of breast self exams (sensitive topic with a lot of emotions from different corners so I’m not touching that one)
This info is according to uptodate (subject to change) and primary care text book. There may be different info in different references but this info is what’s commonly used by myself and peers.

It seems to me that the definition of evaporation should just be expanded, since that more accurately describes what's going on. Inventing a 3rd term is really adding more confusion, not clearing anything up. The reason is that in the sciences we like to be a bit more specific about grouping similar things together. We observe patterns, and group them together for utility. Unless I'm missing something fairly basic here, there's nothing fundamentally different happening between evaporation from a liquid, and evaporation happening from a solid.

We differentiate between boiling/melting/condensing/freezing because these are all different phase transitions. Something similar happens when creating a plasma, or bose-einstein condensate, and we categorize all of these as different states of matter. If you want to get deep into physics, there's a 6th, which is a quark-gluon plasma, where particles aren't even bound by the strong nuclear force anymore.

So if that's fundamentally the same process, why invent a 3rd term for the same process? The two are directly related, so we should use the same word for them. Words are really just tools and "convenient ways of thinking of things" rather than reality itself. In both processes we have a state of matter turning into a vapor. Both happen below the "normal" transition temperature, so I think it makes sense to related them together.

Now... I suppose what you're saying is that the important part here is the transition from one state of matter to another should use a different word, just like we do for other transitions. If you wanted to to that, the word should be more related to evaporation, not sublimation, since, as I understand it evaporation is what's really happening here is a transition from a solid into a vapor. Maybe something more like sevaporation, so the concept of evaporation is still evident, but distinguish it from a liquid evaporation? Or at least something based on the root word "vaporation", to connect it to vaporizing, which is what's going on here.

Sublimation is fascinating... It takes 720 calories of heat to sublimate one cubic cm of water, but only 80 to melt that same cubic cm of water. The energy cost to sublimate is the same as melting (80cal), then raising it up to the boiling temp (100cal) and then vaporizing (540cal).

So this really has a huge impact in winter when there's snow on the ground. The snow and ice are always sublimating off, consuming vast amounts of heat right out of the air and ground.

For ANY sublimation, the "pressure" is below the triple-point pressure.  The fact that "there are other gasses hanging around in the same space" is not relevant (as long as they are not chemically reacting with substance in question).  Iodine in the gently-heated beaker has a PARTIAL pressure less then triple point.  If I take the experiment to high altitude (where atmospheric pressure matched the iodine's vapor pressure), the process would still be the same.  Only when we crank up the heat (while at high altitude) do "boundary conditions" FORBID the temperature climbing to the triple point, and "you can't melt iodine".

The classic definition of melting point is, that temperature at which the solid and liquid phase of a substance, coexist at equilibrium under the pressure of it's own vapor. If you understand this, you may see that his experiment really didn't show that. However. he is nevertheless correct in stating that iodine melts. Melting is pressure dependent, but the reality is, we usually accept that pressure to be one atmosphere. Anything can surely exist in any state, I know CO2 is stored as a liquid, even though it can't become a stable liquid at atmospheric pressure, I'd imagine that because there are small variations in pressure and temperature along the boundary between the solid and gas phases, where tiny amounts do exist briefly as a liquid, as you reach it's triple point the boundaries  just widen very quickly. It depends the boundaries between different states is just away for us to describe apparent behavioural traits gases and liquids behave in similar ways, it becomes even more blurred as it gets closer to the supercritical  zone, at an atomic level are they behaving radically different, they are essentially being forced by an external force to assume an intermediate state where they have too much kinetic energy to  remain solid but not enough to overcome the force of gravity or the walls of a vessel pushing back, at supercritical point the boundaries blur again and the distinction between liquid and gas becomes practically non existent, could almost think of the three as being phases of a single fluid state.

Evaporation has to do with the partial pressure not the total pressure.  Your phase change charts are a measure of total pressure i.e. they are based on the contents of the container are ONLY that substance (vapor-liquid-solid); there is no vapor, liquid, or solid of another substance.  So, yes, you are correct, there is liquid iodine, but only when you drive off the air to create a liquid-vapor iodine interface (in your case by applying more heat), AND the phase diagram is also correct that it sublimates, the partial pressure due to the air makes it appear the pressure is lower than it is.

Though I aggree with the general theory discussed, the nilation nomenclature is unfortunately based on a misunderstanding. Boiling is a result of a high rate of phase change. The temperature of the edge of the kettle or beaker in this case is higher than the rest of the beaker. This leads to what is called boiling. This means the phase change rate is localized causing bubbling. There are different types of boiling: film boiling and nucleate bubbling and are somewhat arbitrarily differentiated by the rates causing bubbling or simply instantly vaporizing at the surface. If the rate is slow enough, no bubbles will be observed. Sublimation is the change from solid to vapour directly, which in this case is happening in concert with the evaporation as the heating does not happen slowly enough to form a stable liquid before evaporating. So the nilation nomenclature, though quirky and fun, is unecessary and erroneous.

Maybe Nilation or Subvaporation. The term sublimation will only refer to when the substance reaches the sublimation point. The higher the pressure, the higher the sublimation point until it goes above the triple point. Then it's the boiling point. While Nilation or Subvaporation can occur at any temperature and is similar to evaporation except it's for solids and not liquids. Evaporation is for liquids, Subvaporation is for solids. Sublimation + Evaporation = Subvaporation.

I think sublimation is simply defined as the process of solid directly turns to gas with no liquid phase in between. The reason evaporation is different from boiling is because evaporation only applies to the surface turning to gas and boiling applies to any part of the liquid becoming gas. And the reason we don't need a new word for sublimation under boiling point is because only the surface becomes gas due to slow conduction of heat (liquid can transfer heat through convection). Therefore resulting in the same thing and no need to confuse people to terms that have no observable differences. Honestly, think of writing a lab report and try describing what an unknown solid is doing. For liquid, if you see bubbles appear rapidly and floating to the surface without prior mixing with other chemicals, you know it is boiling. If the liquid sits there with smoke floating out, you know it is evaporation. But for solid, should I write about seeing sublimation or 'nilation'. Because they are same thing, there is no such need for new names. If you really like new names so much, you should name both sublimation processes and categorize under sublimation, so only the people who study these stuff need to learn the words and the common folk can stick to sublimation.

honestly sounds like a reasonable term. It makes sense that we dont have separate words for these because we often use these processes in our daily lives. Here's a handy way to think of sublimation. Sublimation is what we call the phase change of a substance where the evaporation or boiling rate of a substance is faster than or equal to rate that the substance melts. You could image a scenario where the evaporation conversion rate of liquid to gas is 1.1ng/cm^2 and the melting conversion rate of the substance is 1ng/cm^2 in this scenario the melt evaporates faster then it forms so unless you have capacity to view a dynamic process on the nano scale you would be unable to see the melt.

back in 1972 (I was 13) I was taught that sublimation is just the transision of material from solid to gas or visa versa.  We were told about this property just before being tasked (as a practical) to find the boiling point and melting point of Iodine.  From memory I recall the melting point (at atmospheric pressure) was a bit higher than that of water, while it's boiling point was surprisingly low (certainly less than 200C). (and hence needed to be expected while conducting our investigation).  It was around this time we also explored the properties of sulphur. hi Nile! chemical engineering student here. boiling and evaporation are actually the same thing. pool boiling occurs in a stepwise fashion depending on the temperature gradient of a substance— first free convection boiling, then nucleate, transition, and film boiling. the evaporation video you put first most closely shows free convection boiling, which occurs when small bubbles of vapor gather and begin to evaporate, while the traditional “boiling” occurs during nucleate/transition boiling. VLE (vapor liquid equilibrium) is very similar to SVE (solid vapor equilibrium) in that they occur through points on a phase diagram (pressure, temp dependency), but to my knowledge these are not distinct phases like in pool boiling that are dependent on the temperature gradient, rather the temperature gradient does not affect sublimation in easily detectable, separable stages. thus the need for this term has not yet arisen, but I would assume there are thermodynamic research labs that study this phenomenon!!

Use of phase diagrams in 7:15 and 8:08 is slightly incorrect. Those are single component phase diagram, and strictly speaking do not represent water-air or iodine-air system (where air is a mixture of gasses). Under an atmosphere, single component phase diagram, have to be used carefully (or just go with multi component phase diagram, but good luck with that).

Water under an air atmosphere and at temperatures below boiling is in a single phase, only if there is not enough water to begin with. When you enter the room in your apartment, you can see all that single phase water vapour. OK, maybe not see it, but it is there.

Given enough water below boiling point, it will never be in a single phase. It is just that we don't see that gas phase. As temperature rises, the equilibrium phases of water (not considering many different ice phases) will be: gas/solid (T<273.15K) -> gas/liquid/solid (T=273.15K) -> gas/liquid (273.15K<T<373.15K), until at high enough temperatures water turns to single gas phase. The useful information from single component phase diagram is the partial pressure of a gas phase. This shortcut is possible as gasses under these conditions are non-interacting and close to ideal gases .

Further complication arise between melting point and triple point temperatures. In that region, partial pressure of a gas phase cannot be read from the phase diagram, as equilibrium between the stable phase (e.g. liquid water) and a gas phase is not drawn. This is because liquid/gas equilibrium at those temperatures is not present in the single component system (e.g. isolated system with only only water, no other gases).

I lean towards the opposite idea for the sublimation problem. I would rather expand the definitions and reduce the words. We could say if something moves from anywhere to gas it would be one term, to liquid another term, and to solid a third term. Or we could go beyond that and say moving up the scale from solid to liquid or liquid to gas would be one term, and the other direction would be another. Then instead of sublime we could just use the term "melt" as children tend to always lean towards, and if we want to be very specific we could say something like "double melt" or "melts below the triple point pressure". I'd personally prefer the first suggestion of terms equal the end point like "solid iodine boiled above the triple point", but either would be preferable to adding more terms to me.

I guess the definition is based on whether nucleation process is involved or not. The phase transformaion between solid and gas generally only occurs on the surface, since nucleation in such case requirs not only extremely difficult-to-create temperature distribution that might be possible by focusing multiple laser beams, but also a sufficiently low ΔG (or high in negative) that overcomes the energy needed to form new surfaces out of nowhere while creating a space to hold those newly formed gas, which is probably inplausible since solids hardly deform. However nucleation in liquid-to-gas phase transition requires significantly higher (or lower in negative) ΔG owing to the liquids' ability to deform given a pressure gradient. Thus the term "boiling" is specified to the phenomenon that bubbles forming in a liquid due to nucleation when the conditions, including the equilibrium vapor pressure of that liquid is greater than the environmental pressure at the nucleation site, are met. And since solid-to-gas phase change may usually be dscribed as, without extra nucleation process, the substance on its surface simply moved from point A to point B on a phase diagram, either vertically (vapor pressure < equilibrium VP), horizontally (increasing in temperature with the ending point equilibrium in gas phase under same pressure), or some combination of both, I see no purpose to seperate sublimation process into two categories. In other words, its an undistinguishable continuum.

Note that Iodine's triple point is at 0.12 atmospheres, so at a much higher pressure than water with 0.006 atmospheres. That means that - under normal pressure (1 atmosphere) - the steam coming off solid iodine is much denser than the steam coming off solid water (aka ice). To the point that people incorrectly believe that you cannot melt sold iodine at normal pressure.

I would define it this way:
Sublimation = Solid to gas phase change
Melting = Solid to liquid phase change
Boiling = Liquid to gas phase change
Evaporation = High-energy minority of molecules escaping into gaseous state above phase change pressure/below phase change temperature, broken down into Solid Evaporation (colloquially known as sublimation) and Liquid Evaporation (colloquially known as evaporation).

EDIT: Reading through the comments I found this:
Evaporation is what happens when a liquid crosses the liquid-gas line on the diagram ("boiling").
Spontaneous evaporation is when a liquid doesn't cross the line but still becomes gaseous ("evaporation").
Sublimation is what happens when a solid crosses the solid-gas line on the diagram.
Spontaneous sublimation is what happens when the solid doesn't cross the line but still becomes gaseous. (Is this what you call nilation?)

Now I wonder: Is there also spontaneous melting? It would probably have to be a solid that's covered in its liquid form, right? And if you wipe it off there would be again a liquid layer forming but the temperature would be below the melting point at which all of the solid would turn liquid. Does something like this exist?
IMO, this normal vs spontaneos nomenklature makes a whole lot more sense than inventing new words altogether to describe a process that's just slightly different.

I recommend terms based on pressure and temperature.
1. If the pressure is raised does it solidify? Solidification.
2. If the pressure is raised does it break apart? Vitreous point.
3. If the pressure is lowered does it solidify? Hardening.
4. If the pressure is lowered does it break? Deformation.
5. If the temperature is raised, does it change from solid to liquid? Melting.
6. If the temperature is raised, does it change from liquid to gas? Boiling
7. If the temperature is raised, does it change from solid to gas? Evaporation.
8. If the temperature is lowered does it change from liquid to solid? Freezing.
9. If the temperature is lowered, does it change from gas to liquid? Condensation.
10. If the temperature is lowered, does it change from gas to solid? Cyrogenation.

Terms should be made using water as the basis for temperature, because it is also the basis of our measurement of the gram. Is from a cubic centimeter of water. We use gram often when talking about mass. These changes greatly affect the volume of the object but the gram would be the best way to account for the changes happening to it. With water we observe similar changes happening when heat is taken away or given but there are no conflicts at atmospheric pressure. Which I feel does happen with iodine and that is why it's bad to make a term based on iodine's problems.

The terms should also use 1 atmospheric pressure as the base line because we live on earth and the times we'd practically experience anything else would happen with the inclusion or exclusion of water. [We lose water in the air as we go up into the sky and we gain more water as we go down into the ocean.]

The situations we experience with Iodine is Evaporation. Not boiling or melting. Similar to how people say it sublimates except that sublimation is a term that I feel goes against scientific uniformity. As you also stated I feel like everything can evaporate but at different rates, at such such points that when compared to water's temperature when solid that it's almost non existent. It's not remarkable at all that solids become liquid when heat is added. Vaporizing however is a pretty big deal and as you stated the bonds of something has to be pretty weak for it to visibly vaporize from a solid at freezing the freezing level of water. Heating it up does make the process happen faster but that isn't remarkable either as most substances on the planet would react the same way to being heated. It's the fact that it's bonds are so weak that at base atmospheric pressure it barely can keep together that makes it remarkable/different.

By correctly using terms to explain the differences of things, people can relay that information more reliable. Like if it turned into a liquid from a solid at the same freezing temperature as water. That's pretty remarkable. Nobody cares at that point if adding pressure or removing pressure will change this, unless it too requires very little change and so it becomes less certain that it is the key factor. Usually when it comes to observing, a person tries to limit the observations to 1 variable changing under a controlled environment. While other variables can be changed later when it comes to making basic terms, this is how most scientists would do it.

So basically. Iodine is remarkable because at atmospheric pressure it requires no added joules at water's freezing point to go from solid to gas. This change I would simply call evaporation as it vaporizes itself directly to gas. Heat helps but is not required at this point for the same mass of iodine to completely vaporize. Heat is part of the factor when it comes to boiling, which is not required for iodine to reach a gaseous state. This is basically what the video is about. Iodine doesn't need to reach boiling in order to evaporate.

Interesting bit of trivia regarding the lowering of iodine's melting point -- In 1932, the Czech physicist Paul Kubelka discovered that if liquid iodine is adsorbed by activated charcoal, it will remain liquid at temperatures as much as 100 C below iodine's normal melting point. The surface energy of the iodine inside the activated carbon's pores is so great that it lowers the melting point of the iodine. So surface tension can alter the phase diagram.
Kubelka, Paul (July 1932) "Über den Schmelzpunkt in sehr engen Capillaren" (On the melting point in very narrow capillaries), Zeitschrift für Elektrochemie und angewandte physikalische Chemie (Journal for Electrochemistry and Applied Physical Chemistry), 38 (8a) : 611–614. Available on-line in English translation at: National Research Council Canada: http://nparc.cisti-icist.nrc-cnrc.gc.ca/eng/view/object/?id=7cc32d53-ea4b-404c-8ab7-0d2b0a7df283

I am used to differentiate the two kinds of substances that undergo sublimation by calling one of them 'subliming typically' (for which the triple point is above atmospheric pressure) and the other - 'subliming non-typically' (triple point below atmospheric pressure). But again, this does not take into account that even the substances that sublime 'typically', can also sublime at lower temperatures but at slower rate.
So, yes, I agree that probably a new term is indeed necessary. But I'd rather think sublimation has to be analogous to evaporation and the missing term should be analogous to boiling. This is because, according to some thesauruses, sublimation means 'uplifting' or 'elevation'. I could be wrong, but this seems to me closer to evaporation (becoming steam) than to boiling (which has the meaning of 'bubbling').
It is a tricky matter. No wonder it hasn't been settled so far.

Hi Nile and other viewers, maybe you have 5 minutes to read this and help me with my understanding of atomic vibrations.
I have found the same statements as you explained in 4:07 ... so basically what I have found was: If you look at the anharmonic potential energy curve you will see that as you heat a lot of materials the internuclear seperation shifts to a wider mean distance, resulting in thermal expansion. OK... so basically what the potential energy curve is saying is that the amplitude of the quantized atomic vibrations increases if you add the right amount of energy to the material. I think you can imagine the vibrations to be like atoms being connected by springs. At the bottom, the anharmonic curve is approximately parabolic, so that's why the spring model, which has a harmonic curve works. Also the energy levels of possible vibrations are so fine, that it apperas like the atoms would oscillate around continuously or smoothly. If the vibrations are transfered to neighboring atoms in a crystal, these vibrations are called phonons... ok so much for the scientific facts in a few sentences.

First question: The atomic vibration frequency of almost all organic molecules (crystalline or not) is in the range of 10^12-10^14 Hz which is equal to IR-radiation. So by resonace these Materials can be heated. But how come so many people and websites say that by heating a material the frequency of atomic vibrations gets larger? It would basically mean that the characteristic absorption bands would shift to different frequencies in IR-spectroscopy if you heated a small sample of the material by that statement.

Second question: What is the vibration frequency of metals? Is it also in the range of 10^12-10^14 Hz? In my opinion it has to be, because metals absor IR and turn them into optical phonons.

Third question: What are the mechanics of heat conduction in amorphous materials like glass and amorphous polystyrene for example? The vibrations are not called phonons anymore in amorphous materials. I have found they are called "diffusons" but the explanation for conduction in these materials was very unclear for me.

What we actually need, is a word for "to sublimate away"!

Sublimation is similar to boiling but not to evaporation. Sublimation and boiling refer to the process of a phase transition (solid to gas and liquid to gas).
When we say something evaporates we mean it "boils away". We mean that individual molecules have enough energy to make the transition from liquid to gas, and since evaporation implies an open system, it "boils away".
This means dry ice sublimates when above −78.5°C at 1atm, but iodine does not! it "sublimates away", just like dry ice kept below −78.5°C at 1atm in an open container.

So yeah, iodine can't sublimate at 1atm, it can only "sublimate away" (in an open container) or boil.
A different way to put it would be that iodine does not sublimate nor "sublimate away" in a closed container at room temperature and atmospheric pressure (happens to be a solid according the phase diagram), just like water in a closed container at room temperature and atmospheric pressure (happens to be a solid according the phase diagram) does not boil nor "boil away"/evaporate.

+NileRed — As a linguist, I'm curious about the etymology of your new term. At first glance I would take it not as a term for something converting into gas or vapor but as a term for something vanishing into nothingness. Have you considered starting by dropping the "e" prefix from "evaporation"? Currently, the tern "vaporization" has to do with becoming gas or vapor regardless of from which state, while "evaporation" refers to "vaporatization" "ex-" or "out of" (French: "e-") the liquid state. So vaporation could be used as a sort of "vaporization" not out of liquid. Alternatively, "disfirmation" would literally mean the process of "scattering from solid" which is really what you're talking about. Is it not? Likewise, "defirmation" could be used for the process of "coming out of solid form" regardless of whether into liquid or into gas. Actually, »Nilation« and Sublimation is the same thing, but there is a misconception about in the phase-diagram: It does not depend on the absolute pressure, but the partial pressure, which is way below the absolute pressure, as long the concentration of iodine is low. If the beaker is full of iodine gas, solid iodine will not sublimate, but melt and boil. Until then, the absolute pressure is more or less the same. This is different with ›real‹ sublimation. Even if the beaker is full of carbon dioxide gas, dry ice will sublimate and increase the pressure. The phase-diagram is only true, if all phases you look at are of the same substance. The phase-diagram is only true, if you have a liquid phase of water above a solid phase of water, otherwise even ice will sublimate at normal pressure and below the melting-point. The phase-diagram is also not true, if you have just one phase of the substance, for example liquid water below the melting point. This is not going to freeze as long you do not have a second, solid phase of water. (You probably already know this as super-cooling)

Let's be careful with our definitions here. Sublimation, proper, means that a temperature change causes a material to phase transition. This is anologous to boiling. For sublimation, proper, to happen it's a necessary, but not sufficient criterion that the reaction is below the triple point. It also needs to happen at the phase transition curve, aka the sublimation curve. Spontaneous "evaporation" from a solid however is the same phenomenon both above and below the triple point, so long as it happens left of the melting and sublimation curves. And I don't personally like the word nilation because it sounds like a process for making nylon. I'd probably just call it spontaneous sublimation or perhaps solid evaporation, to reuse existing terminology as much as possible.

The thing about sublimation is that you don't have internal pressure blowing the substance apart, like you do with vaporization. I assume that's just because the rate of heat transfer is too slow to allow anything but the surface to exceed the vaporization point.

If you did, and the phase change wasn't confined to the surface, then you'd get something much more skin to boiling. However, I would expect that the term used would then be "explode", since a solid -> gas phase change throughout the mass is going to be pretty violent.

First, thanks for this video, I actually learned that Iodine has a melting point at atmospheric pressure!

Secondly, although most of the explanations were good, I'm not quite satisfied with some of your explanations. I don't blame you since thermodynamics can be a quite finicky subject.

The key term here that you should have mentionned earlier is vapour pressure As you said a vapour pressure is present for any solid or liquid. This is what is represented on a phase diagram.

The boiling point simply describes a set of temperature and atmospheric pressure for which the vapour pressure of a liquid is equal to the atmospheric pressure, an equilibrium point .

From a thermodynamic stand point, boiling is not something remarquable.
Boiling is just the fast evaporation of a liquid at it's equilibrium point.
Vaporisation is the general term for the transition from a liquid to a solid. In some context, it can be distinguised as either evaporation or boiling.
Sublimation is the general term for the transition from a solid to a gaz. As far as I know no differentiation exist for different kind of sublimation.

In the case of iodine, what we witness is a fast sublimation from non-equilibrium conditions due to the high vapour pressure of iodine.
For dry ice, we have sublimation from an equilibrium state (vapour pressure of CO2 is the same as atmospheric pressure and temperature of the dry ice stays the same during the whole process).

I think the reason why we have different terms for boiling and evaporation is more of a practical one than a theoretical one. We can see a difference between boiling water and evaporating water, but there is no visual cue between sublimation and "nilation".

So I'd argue that we're not missing a term for describing a change from solid to gas. If we want to follow your logic and be rigorous, we'd have to introduce another term for the sublimation at equilibrium. In such a case I'd like to reserve the term SuperSamation :p

Otherwise, very nice video. It made me think alot!

It would be very neat to do a video about supercritical fluids and their applications - one application is a family of materials called aerogels: they are normal gels, like jello or silica gel that has had the liquid component taken beyond the critical point, and turned into gas without evaporation... this process does not collapse the gel "skeleton" structure, so you have a very light, very insulative material with a very high surface area. They have been used for insulation, but have also been looked into for making highly efficient capacitors or reaction catalysts.
If you have access to the lab apparatus, you can create a gel with alcohol or acetone as the liquid component, and immerse it in liquid CO2 - using a miscible solvent like ethanol or acetone means the liquid in the gel will be replaced by liquid CO2. Then you can take the (now very cold) liquid CO2 gel and autoclave it, increasing the pressure and temperature around the critical point.

I'am failing to see why "nilation" should be a thing. In lab practice Gibbs phase diagrams (that You have presented quite nicely) are in common use, to solve phase transition related problems. It is easier to convey meaning to students via simplified models - nobody is teaching that sum of two velocity vectors with same orientation, magnitude of let's say 2 and direction is not equal 4. It is equal under Newtonian physics, but as we now know special relativity is better, and velocities don't simply add up.

Additionally you shown in 8:39 wrong section of Gibbs diagram. Diagram You have presented clearly depicts effect that change in temperature and pressure have on melting point - Clausius Clapeyron equation describes this. (Melting "point" is that almost vertical line above Triple Point - I know that You know but that wasn't clear in the video ^^). Plus solids can't "boil". This term is reserved to liquids only, and in the volume of a liquid bubbles of "saturated vapour" has to appear to fulfill the definition. So yea, in the first case when solid is changed directly into gas we have sublimation, when liquid changes into gas we have evaporation, when solid changes into liquid we have melting. I don't see place for additional term here.

I have to disagree. We treat boiling and evaporation as separate because evaporation occurs only from the surface, whereas boiling happens from the entire mass of the liquid at the same time. This results in two visually and physically different processes.  But for solids, there is no good equivalent for boiling, as it always happens at the surface. Consequently, it is not very useful to differentiate between Sublimation and "Nilation" as they are essentially the same process.

9:45 I think the reason why that distinction is not made for sublimation is that with evaporation and boiling, the phenoma are qualitatively different - in evaporation, liquid only goes over to vapour at the interface between the bulk liquid and the surrounding air, while in boiling, because the liquid's vapour pressure is strong enough to open up bubbles against atmospheric pressure, transition to vapour can happen all throughout.

But with solids that sublime (and whose triple point is above atmospheric pressure), the vapour pressure generally is not strong enough to open up voids against the mechanical strength that holds the solid together, and so sublimation still only happens at the surface.

Confirmation bias is actually the probable explanation for the origin of the myth. We learn that carbon dioxide sublimes, and indeed, liquid carbon dioxide can't exist under standard atmospheric conditions. "Great! Really cool!" we say, having discovered something that is, aside from being really cool, completely counterintuitive and sticks in our minds more strongly because of that reason. We then learn that iodine also sublimes. We see some pictures or a demonstration and, indeed, it sublimes. "Wow! So awesome!" we say, having made an observation that is superlatively rad, dude. The problem is that the nonexistence of the liquid carbon dioxide phase stuck in our minds to the point that we also attributed that property to iodine, and the two share the property that both sublime. However, we don't actively try to disprove ourselves, as human beings, because of confirmation bias and other cognitive biases, which are literally chemical pathways in the ways our brains are constructed. There can be no elimination of our cognitive biases, since they are relics of our evolutionary heritage. We can only be aware of their existence, and try to mitigate and minimize their impact as much as possible. The explanation of the ubiquity of the myth is confirmation bias.
